title: 112_s3463
content: The Act titled "Medicare Diabetes Prevention Act of 2012" aims to address diabetes prevention under the Medicare program. The Medicare Diabetes Prevention Act of 2012 focuses on expanding coverage for diabetes prevention program services under the Social Security Act. The Medicare Diabetes Prevention Act of 2012 expands coverage for diabetes prevention program services under the Social Security Act by adding a new subsection. The Medicare Diabetes Prevention Act of 2012 expands coverage for diabetes prevention program services by adding new subsections for eligible individuals and qualified providers. The Medicare Diabetes Prevention Act of 2012 expands coverage for diabetes prevention programs by establishing criteria for qualified providers and programs in accordance with National Diabetes Prevention Program standards. The Medicare Diabetes Prevention Act of 2012 expands coverage for diabetes prevention programs by allowing items and services to be furnished in a community setting. The Secretary can establish procedures for qualified providers to contract with delivery partners to offer these services. Delivery partners include entities like non-profit organizations, hospitals, and health centers that meet specific criteria set by the Secretary in line with National Diabetes Prevention Program standards. The Medicare Diabetes Prevention Act of 2012 allows coverage for diabetes prevention programs in community settings. The Secretary can establish criteria for qualified providers to offer services through delivery partners, including non-profit organizations and health centers, in accordance with National Diabetes Prevention Program standards. A qualified diabetes prevention program provider, as determined by the Secretary, may include various entities such as suppliers, service providers, health insurance companies, and community-based organizations. They are required to offer services through a delivery partner unless none are available. The qualified diabetes prevention program provider must manage and track program outcomes, implement business processes, verify billing accuracy, comply with laws, and engage with partners. The qualified diabetes prevention program provider must engage with eligible individuals, comply with program integrity requirements, and perform other functions as established by the Secretary. Additionally, payment for items and services furnished under the program is specified in the Social Security Act. The Social Security Act specifies payment for services provided under a diabetes prevention program, with the amount paid being 100 percent of the actual charge or the fee schedule amount determined by the Secretary. Additionally, a waiver of the deductible application is applied to certain covered OPD services. The Social Security Act specifies payment for services under a diabetes prevention program, with a waiver of the deductible for these services. Amendments include the assignment of claims to qualified diabetes prevention program providers and the exclusion of program items from skilled nursing facility payments. Amendments to the Social Security Act include the inclusion of items and services under a diabetes prevention program in qualified health center services. Special consideration is given to the dual eligible population in implementing these changes. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will give special consideration to individuals who are dually eligible for Medicare and Medicaid benefits. An evaluation will be conducted on the coverage of items and services under a diabetes prevention program in the Medicare program, including the impact on Medicare beneficiaries. The impact of coverage under a diabetes prevention program in the Medicare program on various populations, referral rates by physicians, beneficiary participation levels, and health outcomes. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will submit a report to Congress by January 1, 2018, on the evaluation of a diabetes prevention program under Medicare, along with recommendations for legislation and administrative actions. The amendments made by paragraphs (1) through (6) will apply to services furnished on or after January 1, 2014. The Medicare Physician Quality Reporting System will now include a measure for referrals to diabetes prevention programs. Additionally, a diabetes risk assessment will be included in Medicare's Personalized Prevention Plan. The Security Act is amended to include an assessment for diabetes risk in personalized prevention plans starting January 1, 2014. The Security Act is amended to include an assessment for diabetes risk in personalized prevention plans starting January 1, 2014. SEC. 3. FINDINGS; SENSE OF THE SENATE REGARDING DIABETES PREVENTION UNDER THE MEDICAID PROGRAM. The National Diabetes Prevention Program, established by the CDC, reduces diabetes onset by 58% in at-risk adults. Congress finds Medicaid will cover 13 million with diabetes by 2020, costing $83 billion. Senate believes the program can help reduce diabetes in Medicaid enrollees.
